bib_record.title: The C(alpha,X)11C cross sections at 1.59 and 4.19 GeV

free_txt: The Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory
Bevalac.
The gamma-ray spectrometer itself consisted
of a 20.32 cm diameter by 10.16 cm thick NaI(Tl)
crystal coupled through a linear amplifier to a 1600
channel pulse height analyzer.
For alpha detection.
Ion chambers ICl-3: The readout from these
chambers provided a monitor for the stability of the
beam at the high intensities. These ion chamber
readings were also used to record the time
distribution of the incident beam during the course of
a given irradiation.
Systematic plus statistical. The errors in
the cross section are dominated by possible counting
losses in the two scintillator system and effects due
to slight misalignment of the beam.
Possible counting losses as reflected by the
difference in counts between the two sets of
electronics never amounted to more than 2%.
An error contribution of 2% was assigned to
allow for possible slight misalignment of the beam
during irradiation.
The Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory
Bevalac.
The duration of the entire irradiation
procedure was about 3-4 hours. During the
irradiations, the beam position and intensity were
visually monitored on a pulse-by-pulse basis, and the
accumulated incident flux was manually recorded after
every 10 spills. The 11C was counted using a NaI(Tl)
gamma-ray spectrometer. An irradiated polystyrene
target was sandwiched between a pair of 0.157 cm
thick copper plates, an the gamma rays from the
annihilation of the beta+ from the 11C decay were
measured in the spectrometer. The central disk and
the annulus of each polystyrene target were counted
separately.
A polystyrene target consisted of a 3.81 cm diameter
circular disk which was closely fitted inside a
circular annulus whose diameter was 7.62 cm. The
pieces were constructed to have parallel faces and a
nominal thickness of 1.57 mm. The carbon content
(12C+13C) of polystyrene is 91.5% carbon by weight.
Each graphite target block had nominal dimensions of
(5.1 x 5.1x2.54 cm3). The dimensions and weight of
each graphite target used were measured and recorded.
